sessions.title: A Secret Swift Tour
sessions.description: When you started learning Swift, maybe you played 'A Swift Tour', the official tutorial from Apple. But as time passed, you started to understand and get used to Swift. Let's play 'A Secret Swift Tour'.
sessions.description_ja: Swift ã‚’å­¦ã³å§‹ã‚ã‚‹ã¨ãã€Apple ã®å…¬å¼ãƒãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒªã‚¢ãƒ« 'A Swift Tour' ã«å–ã‚Šçµ„ã‚“ã æ–¹ã‚‚å¤šã„ã®ã§ã¯ãªã„ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã‹ã€‚ ãã—ã¦ã€æ™‚ã‚’çµŒã¦ã€Swift ã«æ…£ã‚Œè¦ªã—ã‚“ã ä»Šã ã‹ã‚‰ã“ãç†è§£ã—ã€å¾—ã‚‰ã‚Œã‚‹ã‚‚ã®ãŒã‚ã‚Šã¾ã™ã€‚ã‚‚ã†å°‘ã—æ·±å €ã‚Šã—ãŸ Swift ã®ä¸–ç•Œã€'A Swift Tour' ã®è£é¢ã«å–ã‚Šçµ„ã‚“ã§ã¿ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚

speakers.name: Yuka Ezura
speakers.bio: Yuka Ezura is an iOS engineer working at LINE. She belongs to the cloud AI platform â€œClovaâ€ development team. At conferences and many study meetings, she presents topics focused on Swift language. She is also a personality at a web radio station mookmook radio.
speakers.bio_ja: LINE ã® iOS ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã€‚ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¦ãƒ‰ AI ãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ  Clova é–‹ç™ºãƒãƒ¼ãƒ ã«æ‰€å±ã€‚ã‚«ãƒ³ãƒ•ã‚¡ãƒ¬ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚„å‹‰å¼·ä¼šã§ä¸»ã« Swift ã‚’ä¸­å¿ƒã«ã—ãŸãƒ†ãƒ¼ãƒã§ç™ºè¡¨ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚ã¾ãŸã€web ãƒ©ã‚¸ã‚ªå±€ mookmook radio ã§ãƒ‘ãƒ¼ã‚½ãƒŠãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ã‚’å‹™ã‚ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€‚

sessions.title: SIL for First Time Learners
sessions.description: Swift compiler runs in multiple phases and one of the biggest one is SIL optimizations. The SIL optimizer performs all the important Swift-specific optimizations, so I believe that itâ€™s quite valuable to have understanding about SIL as Swift developer. In this talk, weâ€™ll go over basic idea of SIL with simple examples.

speakers.name: Yusuke Kita
speakers.bio: Yusuke Kita is an iOS developer at Mercari. He works on the internationalization of the Mercari app. He's passionate about learning new technology. When not coding, you can find him cycling.

sessions.title: Exploring Clang Modules
sessions.description: Swift and Objective-C frameworks share the same underlying module system, based upon Clang Modules. They are intended to replace header files as a way of communicating the interface for a library, but they come with their own set of edge cases. We will examine how Clang modules are able to replace `#import` statements, some of the consequences of using modules, and how the design of Clang modules has influenced Swift's library story.
sessions.description_ja: Swift ã‚„ Objective-C ã®ãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã¯ Clang ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’ãƒ™ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã¨ã—ãŸåŒã˜ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚·ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ ã‚’å…±æœ‰ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒªã®ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒ•ã‚§ãƒ¼ã‚¹ã¨ã‚„ã‚Šã¨ã‚Šã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ãƒ˜ãƒƒãƒ€ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ã‚’ç½®ãæ›ãˆã¾ã™ãŒã€ãã‚Œãã‚Œã«ã‚¨ãƒƒã‚¸ã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¹ãŒå­˜åœ¨ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚Clang ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã® `#import` æ–‡ã®ç½®ãæ›ãˆæ–¹ã€ãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’ä½¿ã†ã“ã¨ã«ã‚ˆã‚‹å½±éŸ¿ã€Clagnãƒ¢ã‚¸ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã®è¨­è¨ˆãŒSwiftã®ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ–ãƒ©ãƒªã«ã©ã†å½±éŸ¿ã—ã¦ããŸã‹ã‚’èª¿ã¹ã¦ã¿ã¾ã™ã€‚

speakers.name: Samuel Giddins
speakers.bio:
Samuel is a developer well-versed in the rituals of writing developer tools that occasionally work. By day, Samuel works on making the mobile developer experience at Square less arduous; by night he can be found breaking Bundler and CocoaPods.

 Before this whole 'developer' thing, Samuel studied in the highly impractical Mathematics & Economics departments at University of Chicago, learning subjects such as 'numbers', 'social theory', and 'memes'.

When not coding, Samuel is often in the kitchen, marveling at the fact that dinner smells better than it looks.
speakers.bio_ja:
Samuel ã¯é–‹ç™ºè€…å‘ã‘ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚’ä½œã‚‹ã“ã¨ã«ç²¾é€šã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚æ—¥ä¸­ã¯ Square ã«ãŠã‘ã‚‹ãƒ¢ãƒã‚¤ãƒ«é–‹ç™ºè€…ã®è² æ‹…ã‚’æ¸›ã‚‰ã™ã‚ˆã†ãªä»•äº‹ã‚’ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹é–‹ç™ºè€…ã§ã€å¤œã¯Bundler ã¨ CocoaPods ã® Core Contributor ã§ã™ã€‚ 

 é–‹ç™ºè€…ã«ãªã‚‹å‰ã¯ã€ã‚·ã‚«ã‚´å¤§å­¦ã§æ•°å­¦ã‚„çµŒæ¸ˆå­¦ã®å­¦ç§‘ã§ã€ã€Œæ•°ã€ã€ã€Œç¤¾ä¼šç†è«–ã€ã€ã€ŒãƒŸãƒ¼ãƒ ã€ã®ã‚ˆã†ãªç§‘ç›®ã‚’å­¦ã‚“ã§ã—ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ã‚­ãƒƒãƒãƒ³ã«ç«‹ã¤ã“ã¨ãŒå¤šãã€å¤•é£ŸãŒè¦‹ãŸç›®ã‚ˆã‚Šã‚‚ã«ãŠã„ã®æ–¹ãŒè‰¯ã„ã¨ã„ã†äº‹å®Ÿã«é©šã„ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚
speakers.job_title: Bundler & CocoaPods Core Team, Developer at Square
speakers.job_title_ja: Bundler & CocoaPods Core Team, Developer at Square

sessions.title: Getting to Know the Responder Chain
sessions.description: I'll provide an explanation about how the Responder Chain pattern works, how it exists in Apple's frameworks, and give some examples of how to take advantage of it.

speakers.name: Samuel Goodwin
speakers.bio: Samuel has worked on iOS since the SDKâ€™s first release and has been in Amsterdam for the last 6 years running his company, Roundwall Software. He rides skateboards, plays bass guitar, and rides bikes.

sessions.title: Optimizing Swift code for separation of concerns and simplicity
sessions.description: Separating concerns in code is often seen as a premature optimization when code doesnâ€™t need to be reused, but it has huge implications in our ability to comprehend what code does. Letâ€™s explore examples of this in Swift in what I like to call 'separating what code does from how it does what it does'.

speakers.name: Javier Soto
speakers.bio: Javier Soto. Spanish, iOS developer in the SF Bay Area for the past 5 years. Worked at Pebble and Twitter before, now at Twitch. Big fan of Swift. When not writing code, he's playing chess, solving Rubik's cubes or flying planes
speakers.bio_ja: Javier Soto ã¯ã‚¹ãƒšã‚¤ãƒ³å‡ºèº«ã§ã€SFã®ãƒ™ã‚¤ã‚¨ãƒªã‚¢ã§5å¹´é–“iOSã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã‚’ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ä»¥å‰ã¯ã€ Pebble ã‚„ Twitter ã§åƒã„ã¦ã„ã¦ã€ä»Šã¯ Twitch ã«ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚Swift ã®å¤§ãƒ•ã‚¡ãƒ³ã§ã™ã€‚ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚’æ›¸ã„ã¦ã„ãªã„ã¨ãã¯ã€ãƒã‚§ã‚¹ã‚’ã—ãŸã‚Šã€ãƒ«ãƒ¼ãƒ“ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ–ã‚’è§£ã„ãŸã‚Šã€é£›è¡Œæ©Ÿã‚’é£›ã°ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

sessions.title: Should coders design?
sessions.description: Almost all software engineers unanimously agree that the world where designers code is a better world. In this talk I'd like to explore the opposite idea. I'd like to explore how being aware of core design principals will save you time, make your products more resilient to the real-life challenges, improve your communication with users, and help to make smarter, more delightful products.

speakers.name: Sash Zats
speakers.bio: Sash is a software engineer at Facebook working on News Feed. He works on user interaction, animations and experiences that make people smile. Strong believer that, in the future, designers will code and engineers will design because there will be no distinction between two. Days since he broke the like button: 0.

sessions.title: Event driven networking for Swift
sessions.description: Everyone knows that Swift is the language of choice for building apps for iPhone, iPad, Mac, Apple Watch and Apple TV. Over the last couple of years, Swift has also emerged as a great language for developing server applications that run on Linux. Today, most high-scale environments run by companies like Apple, Facebook, Google, Netflix and Twitter use performance-optimized networking frameworks built in Java, C++ and other languages.  This talk will cover how the server infrastructure teams at Apple are using Swift in their development, leveraging years of experience writing high-performance, highly-scalable network applications.
sessions.description_ja: Swift ãŒ iPhone, iPad, Mac, Apple Watch ãã—ã¦ Apple TV ã®ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚’é–‹ç™ºã™ã‚‹è¨€èªã¨ã—ã¦é¸ã°ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã¯ã¿ãªã•ã‚“ã”å­˜çŸ¥ã§ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚ã“ã®æ•°å¹´ã€Swift ã¯ Linux ã§å‹•ä½œã™ã‚‹ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ‰ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’é–‹ç™ºã™ã‚‹ã®ã«ã‚‚å„ªã‚ŒãŸè¨€èªã¨ã—ã¦ã‚‚æµ®ä¸Šã—ã¦ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ç¾åœ¨ã€Apple, Facebook, Google, Netflix, Twitter ãªã©ã®ä¼æ¥­ãŒé‹ç”¨ã™ã‚‹å¤§è¦æ¨¡ãªç’°å¢ƒã§ã¯ã€Javaã€C ++ãªã©ã®è¨€èªã«ã‚ˆã‚‹ã€ãƒ‘ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ³ã‚¹ã«æœ€é©åŒ–ã•ã‚ŒãŸãƒãƒƒãƒˆãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãŒä½¿ã‚ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ã“ã®ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ã§ã¯ã€Apple ã®ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ©ã‚¯ãƒãƒ£ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ ãŒé•·å¹´ã®çµŒé¨“ã‚’æ´»ã‹ã—ã€ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«é«˜æ€§èƒ½ã§ã‚¹ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒ©ãƒ“ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ã®é«˜ã„ãƒãƒƒãƒˆãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã‚’ä½œæˆã—ã¦ã€ã©ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«é–‹ç™ºæ™‚ã«Swiftã‚’åˆ©ç”¨ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã‹ã«ã¤ã„ã¦èª¬æ˜ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

speakers.name: Norman Maurer
speakers.bio: Norman Maurer is a software engineer on the iCloud team at Apple.  He works on the asynchronous network frameworks that underly many of Apple's services.
speakers.bio_ja: Norman Maurer ã¯ Apple ã® iCloud ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ ã®ã‚½ãƒ•ãƒˆã‚¦ã‚§ã‚¢ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã§ã™ã€‚ Apple ã®å¤šãã®ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒ“ã‚¹ã®æ ¹åº•ã«ã‚ã‚‹éåŒæœŸãƒãƒƒãƒˆãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã®ãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯ã«å–ã‚Šçµ„ã‚“ã§ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

sessions.title: The diamond of variance
sessions.description: Generics is always a confusing yet interesting topic in Swift language. Generics Manifesto did a great explanation on how Swift's type system is built for practicality more than principle. But if we look at the theory of 'diamond of variance', we can have another point of view about the completeness of a type system and how Swift generics fit in with the theory.This talk will explain what really is Variance, Covariance, Contravariance in Swift as well as the last amazing piece of above diamond: The Phantom Type.

speakers.name: Vu Nhat Minh
speakers.bio:
Orakaro is an iOS Engineer at Mercari currently working on Atte, the Japanese community classifieds app. Though he had years of backend web programming experiences using languages such as Python or Scala, he decided to move on as a native mobile engineer after figuring out that smartphone apps were doing a better job of impacting the world each and every day. He also enjoys digging around concepts and theories in functional programming, learning abstract algebra and excited to help bring those academy concepts closer to industry products.

In spare time Orakaro enjoys playing the ancient game of Go. He is a 2 dan amateur go player.

sessions.title: SwiftyPi
sessions.description: From mobile development to server-side applications, we are starting to see how flexible the Swift language can be. But there are more frontiers to explore, that unlock new possibilities for Swift developers. In this session, Kate will show you the Good, the Bad and the Ugly of how to set up your Swift Environment in order to develop on a Raspberry Pi.
sessions.description_ja: ãƒ¢ãƒã‚¤ãƒ«é–‹ç™ºã‹ã‚‰ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ‰ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã¾ã§ã€æˆ‘ã€…ã¯Swift è¨€èªã«æŸ”è»Ÿæ€§ã‚’è¦‹å‡ºã ã—å§‹ã‚ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ã§ã™ãŒã¾ã Swiftã«ã¯é–‹æ‹“ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ãªã„é ˜åŸŸãŒã‚ã‚Šã€Swiftã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ãŒãã®å¯èƒ½æ€§ã‚’åˆ‡ã‚Šé–‹ãã‹ã‚‚ã—ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚ã“ã®ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ã§ã¯ã€Kate ãŒ Raspberry Pi ã§ Swift ã®é–‹ç™ºç’°å¢ƒã‚’æ§‹ç¯‰ã™ã‚‹ã«ã‚ãŸã£ã¦è‰¯ã‹ã£ãŸã“ã¨ã€æ‚ªã‹ã£ãŸã“ã¨ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ãŠè©±ã—ã¾ã™ã€‚

speakers.name: Kate Castellano
speakers.bio: Kate Castellano is a Venezuelan Informatics Engineer, specialized in Mobile Development. She started her career as an Android Developer but then decided to change to iOS Development, where she has been working for the past 6 years. One of her passions is to work towards the inclusion of more women in technology, therefore she was the co-organizer of Women Who Go Berlin chapter, Event-Manager for Berlin's Geekettes Mentorship Program and a mentor in Learn It Girl!. She currently works as a Senior iOS Developer for Clue and looks forward to join more organisations. When she is not organising events or coding, you can find her traveling or finding new musicals to sing along to.
speakers.bio_ja: Kate Castellano ã¯ãƒ™ãƒã‚ºã‚¨ãƒ©å‡ºèº«ã®ãƒ¢ãƒã‚¤ãƒ«é–‹ç™ºãŒå¾—æ„ãªã‚½ãƒ•ãƒˆã‚¦ã‚§ã‚¢ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã§ã™ã€‚åˆã‚ã¯ Android ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã®ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã§ã—ãŸãŒã€ä»•äº‹ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¦6å¹´ãŸã£ãŸé ƒã«ã€iOSã®é–‹ç™ºã«ç§»ã‚Šã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ãƒ†ã‚¯ãƒãƒ­ã‚¸ãƒ¼ã«é–¢ã‚ã‚‹å¥³æ€§ã‚’å¢—ã‚„ã™ã“ã¨ã«é«˜ã„æ„æ¬²ã‚’æŒã£ã¦ãŠã‚Šã€Women Who Go Berlin chapter ã®å…±åŒä¸»å‚¬è€…ã‚„ã€ãƒ™ãƒ«ãƒªãƒ³ã® Geekettes Mentorship Program ã®ã‚¤ãƒ™ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒãƒãƒ¼ã‚¸ãƒ£ã€Learn It Girl! ã®ãƒ¡ãƒ³ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚’å‹™ã‚ã¦ã„ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ç¾åœ¨ã¯Clue ã®ã‚·ãƒ‹ã‚¢iOSã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã§ã€ã•ã‚‰ã«å‚ç”»ã™ã‚‹çµ„ç¹”ã‚’æ¢ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ä¼‘ã¿ã®æ—¥ã¯æ—…è¡Œã«å‡ºã‹ã‘ãŸã‚Šã€æ–°ã—ã„ãƒŸãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã‚«ãƒ«ã‚’æ¢ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

sessions.title: Swift in my home
sessions.description: Swift is an indispensable technology for communication in our home. Various things are made utilizing Swift such as iOS client applications for childcare, Web server which receives the request, SlackBot, regularly executed tasks for my chores, and so on. I would like to introduce some selected use-cases among countless possibilities.

speakers.name: Yuki Asai
speakers.bio: Yuki Asai develops iOS apps and server-side apps using Scala. He codes with Swift, Haskell, Ruby, and sometimes ReactNative.
speakers.job_title: iOS Developer at Recruit Marketing Partners
speakers.job_title_ja: iOS Developer at Recruit Marketing Partners

sessions.title: UI Testing for Fun and Profit
sessions.description: Many iOS developers are well-versed in unit testing their applications, but haven't started taking advantage of UI testing within Xcode. Follow me on my journey of implementing UI testing in my app, where I'll share my highlights and struggles of testing all the things.

speakers.name: Sarah Olson
speakers.bio: Sarah Olson is an iOS developer for Trello at Atlassian. She has over eighteen years of development experience in a variety of technologies, including iOS, Android, Java, and WordPress development. As Director of Women Who Code Twin Cities, she leads a variety of initiatives and events focused on creating a more inclusive tech culture. You can follow her on Twitter at @saraheolson.
speakers.bio_ja: Sarah Olsonã¯ Atlassian ã§ Trello ã‚’ä½œã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹ iOS é–‹ç™ºè€…ã§ã™ã€‚ iOS, Android, Java, Wordpress ã‚’å«ã‚€æ§˜ã€…ãªæŠ€è¡“é ˜åŸŸã§18å¹´ä»¥ä¸Šé–‹ç™ºã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ Women Who Code Twin Cities ã®ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã¨ã—ã¦ã€ã‚ˆã‚ŠåŒ…æ‹¬çš„ãªæŠ€è¡“æ–‡åŒ–ã®å‰µé€ ã«ç€ç›®ã—ãŸæ§˜ã€…ãªæ§‹æƒ³ã‚„ã‚¤ãƒ™ãƒ³ãƒˆã‚’ç‡ã„ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚Twitter @saraheolson ã‚’ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ­ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†ã€‚

sessions.title: Writing Blockchain Clients in Swift
sessions.description: An introduction to writing decentralized apps in Swift.

speakers.name: Tamar Nachmany
speakers.bio: Tamar Nachmany has spent the past two years building Tumblr as an iOS engineer on Tumblr's Community, Messaging, and Core iOS teams. She is passionate about learning from technology communities around the world and has given talks about engineering and product design in Germany, Australia, Mexico, the United States, and soon Japan! When she is not writing software she teaches engineering, writes fiction, and organizes an art residency. She lives in New York.
speakers.bio_ja: Tamar Nachmany ã¯ã“ã®ï¼’å¹´é–“ã€iOS ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ã¨ã—ã¦ Tumblr ã®ã‚³ãƒŸãƒ¥ãƒ‹ãƒ†ã‚£ã€ãƒ¡ãƒƒã‚»ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã€ã‚³ã‚¢ iOS ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ ã§ Tumblr ã®é–‹ç™ºã‚’è¡Œã£ã¦ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚å½¼å¥³ã¯ã€ä¸–ç•Œä¸­ã®æŠ€è¡“ã‚³ãƒŸãƒ¥ãƒ‹ãƒ†ã‚£ã‹ã‚‰å­¦ã¶ã“ã¨ã«å¯¾ã—ã¦æƒ…ç†±ã‚’æŒã£ã¦ãŠã‚Šã€ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ãƒªãƒ³ã‚°ã‚„ãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ€ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒ‡ã‚¶ã‚¤ãƒ³ã®ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ã‚’ã“ã‚Œã¾ã§ãƒ‰ã‚¤ãƒ„ã€ã‚ªãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ©ãƒªã‚¢ã€ãƒ¡ã‚­ã‚·ã‚³ã€ã‚¢ãƒ¡ãƒªã‚«ã§è¡Œã£ã¦ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ãã—ã¦ã‚‚ã†ã™ãæ—¥æœ¬ã§ã‚‚ï¼ã‚½ãƒ•ãƒˆã‚¦ã‚§ã‚¢ä»¥å¤–ã§ã¯ã€ã‚¨ãƒ³ã‚¸ãƒ‹ã‚¢ãƒªãƒ³ã‚°ã‚’æ•™ãˆãŸã‚Šã€å°èª¬ã‚’æ›¸ã„ãŸã‚Šã€ã‚¢ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ¬ã‚¸ãƒ‡ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚’çµ„ç¹”ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ãƒ‹ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ãƒ¨ãƒ¼ã‚¯åœ¨ä½ã€‚

sessions.title: Protocol Oriented WebAPI Abstraction
sessions.description: Most applications interact with the server via the Web API. I'd like to show you how to define protocol-oriented API to appropriately design API communication as the foundation of the application and make it easier to repair or change libraries that will be needed in the future. I will also introduce you to the design of a type-safe API abstraction layer combined with RxSwift. I will also show you my AbstractionKit framework.

speakers.name: Yuya Hirayama
speakers.bio: Yuya Hirayama is an iOS engineer at VASILY Inc. He likes the idea of protocol-oriented programming, and pursuing code that realizes type-safe operation with minimal local definition by protocol + protocol extension. Recently, he is pulled toward the strong appeal of server side Swift, focusing more on Swift itself rather than iOS development. Yuya Hirayama also develops a virtual currency service as a side project, including the iOS application and the back-end API using Swift. In addition, he actively speaks at 'iOS Discord' and organizes 'Discord Offline', the first offline event of the community.

sessions.title: ğŸ‘¾
sessions.description: Many indie game developers never use Swift for making their games. Let's develop mobile games in Swift. This session introduces how to develop casual games in Swift using SpriteKit / Game Algorithm / Tools. Become an indie game developer!

speakers.name: Kohki Miki
speakers.bio:
Kohki Miki (a.k.a @giginet) is a software engineer at Cookpad. He builds infrastructure for mobile development and works to improve productivity of mobile developers. Also, he builds fastlane tools, as a member of core contributors, and other useful development tools. 
 
 He likes game development, so he creates some games and writes books about game development.
speakers.bio_ja:

sessions.title: AST Meta-programming
sessions.description: Swift has few  dynamic behavior at run time. I will explore ways to achieve code injection and aspect oriented programming using AST.

speakers.name: Katsumi Kishikawa
speakers.bio: Katsumi Kishikawa is an iOS/macOS developer working at Realm. Heâ€™s a serial open source library developer, and has published some popular libraries on GitHub. Heâ€™s also made big contributions to the iOS developer community in Japan with his experience and knowledge.
